Saints above. Again another impressive building, worth a visit. Not that old, but this is where the wealth of the peoples has been placed.
Simply astounding. Looks terrific from the outside but inside the basilica is absolutely amazing. On a par with St Peter's. Altars, ceilings, walls, organ just stunning.

The most beautiful church. When you go inside it is difficult to know where to look as it positively shines with gilt and marble. From the outside the dome looks quite ordinary but inside it is amazing with paintings and statues. See if you can get tickets to the organ recital on Monday evening which sounds like a 24 piece orchestra but is just a young man playing the organ.

Stunning!. This is the most beautiful building we have ever been in anywhere. We had the privelage of being there at Easter and although the Basillica was quite busy, I was stunned into silence by the magnificance of the building, statues and icons.
Wonderful Architecture.. Lovely Basilica - but too many people "sitting and lounging" on the entrance steps.
Majestic. Huge proporions, beautifully maintained. Free will donations, run by clerics who assue a respectful environment.

Meanest people in Budapest. The people of Budapest were so friendly and nice.... Until we got to the church! Wow we had to laugh at how rude they were. Priest slamming doors in people's faces.. Being extremely gruff with the tourists. Made me wonder which God they serve, cause they weren't happy about it.
Great Views from the Dome. Take time to walk up the many steps to the dome, it's well worth it for the view of the City and the Danube.

Beautiful and offers great views. This is a beautiful church, with an ornate and grand interior. We climbed the tower steps (take the elevator if you can't easily climb 7 flights of stairs) and took in the views from the exterior of the basilica dome. Great 360 view of the city!

Basilica view. St Stephen's Basilica has marvelous interior and exterior architecture. It has a big cupola in which visitors can ascend ( with scales or elevator) after paying a small fee of entrance and from there they can see whole Budapest. The view from there is magnificent. If you have the budapest card there is a discount at the fee entrance.

Beautiful square on the sun. Nice to see and to remmember. Basilica is a hugh with nice square in front. Facade details are great and the street in front lead you directly to Donau in front of Parliament on the right and Chain Bridge on the left.
will be lovely when restoration finished. charged a few bob to get in and only then realised how major the restoration is. Cannot see that much yet
Magnificent views. Very imposing building. You can either climb or take a lift to the top of the tower and the views across Budapest are magnificent
A MUST SEE. The basilica in itself is gorgeous but the panoramic view from the top of the basilica is even more amazing. You'll be able to see the whole of Budapest from the Pest side.
Breathtaking. My sister got married here and what a fabulous setting for a wedding. The decor is breathtaking and the architecture stunning.

great location. It has a great location . What I love about Budapest, as a capital, is that has all atraction close to each other and you do not need a car to go around, to visit, except the Gellert Hill.
The basilica it is very nice on the outside, i did not see it on the interior.

On a par with any cathedral in the world. The Basilica is a wonder. Inside are relics and art worthy of the very best without loosing it's spirituality. Imposing over the city it's worth a visit as is a trip up it's dome.

do not miss. Budapest is not cursed by highrise so the Basilica dominates the city as St Pauls would have done in London years ago. Impressive inside and out - they say there is no charge but the clergy at the entry are very pushy. We gave what we would have freely donated anyway but this was the only downside.

Vac...St. Isztvan. He was a great Christianizer, though somewhat forceful in his methods. Special Papal permission had to gotten to has his statue over the high altar normally always reserved for the figure of Christ.
Great stay at the Budavar Pension. Attend a service there to get a great view of the building and to get a feel for life there.

Very big & beautiful. A quick 10-15 minutes walk through. You do need to pay to get in. It is not really a donation since you can't walk in without handing the guy money, around 1€. You pay additional costs to gomtomthe top as well.
A must see. Actually held my breath when I walked in, it is incredible, definitely should be on your list of places to visit.
amazing. Very powerful energy. Gorgeous church, staggering artwork. We were moved and we're not religious.

Look to it with a good cup of coffee in your hand. The Basilica is placed on a nice spot, surrounded by nice coffee bars and wine bars. So you can enjoy the Basilica by sitting in the sun and staring at it...
Impressive from outside. We were tired to we only saw it from the outside. Enourmous and beautiful.
Great view from top.... This church has been restored and is beautiful. Its' worth the trip to go to the top of the dome and look out over the city. Great photo spot.
stately church in the city center. worth a visit .. one of only a few really beautiful churches

Beautiful church on the Pest side. This church is spectacular by night and day so try to visit it on either occasions.The church is located on the Pest side of town and is in a very pretty area so you will feel safe walking around at night. There are also some restaurants near by but they are pricey (for Budapest standards) but do serve delicious meals!

Very nice. St Stehens basilic is very beautiful and rich. We can see St stephen relich arm, and the basilic has a lot of christian saints, a very beautiful altar, and an amazing cupule. It also has aan very old organ.

Make an effort to sit in their concert. When you visit St. Stephen's basilica, make sure to catch one of their concerts. Great acoustic although the church was freezing during the evening. We were here in March 2012.

absolutely gorgeous!. You should not miss it! It looks small from outside, but in fact it is huge. The roof is stunning, the marbles, paintings and sculptures are just restored and so beautiful! and yes there is a small fee in order to enter, but it makes sense. It is outstanding and to keep it this way someone must pay. Wen you exit the church, look down, the pavement outside is very nice!

Stunning church, but some nickel and diming. The entrance to the basilica is free, but you have to pay a recommended 200 HUF donation per person (and yes, somebody is watching). No big deal, as that's cheap. Church is all that, like most fancy churches. Want to climb the tower? That's another entrance, and another admission fee. Want to see the treasury? Yet another entrance, and another entrance fee. It is a beautiful church though and I consider it a must-do in Budapest. If you need Starbucks afterwards, it 's right out the front door.

Fantastic views - inside and out!. I loved this building - it had been one that I had walked or cycled past quite a few times before actually going inside and it didn't disappoint! Very ornate inside - not to everyone's taste - but I thought it was stunning. We saw the mummified hand of St Stephen and you could put a coin in a machine to see it light up - was a little reminiscent of Blackpool Pleasure Beach - I decided I could forego this excitement. Got the lift up to the top of the dome and thought the views were absolutely stunning. Having been to the Fisherman's Bastion the day before it was really lovely to see views of Budapest from the opposite side. The only reason I haven't given this 5/5 is because of the priest standing over the donations box as you went in - you WILL pay!!!

Definitely worth a visit in Budapest.. St Stephen's a definite visit in Pest. Admission to the Basilica is free and this is the home of the right hand of St. Stephen. You can ride the elevator up the Cupola for a small fee for a beautiful view of the Danube and Castle Hill over in Buda. Gorgeous stained glass and amazing ceilings, including the dome, provide great picture taking opportunities. The alter is something to remember.
What a place. Its hard not to like a nice Basilica and its hard this place is not that old 1851 inside looks much older not to be missed site they say it has the holy right hand of St Stephen.

Terrific Tiled Roof. Although the Basilica was closed when we visited,it would be well worth a visit if the exterior was anything to go by.The tiled roof and spire was terrific and the whole area is worth exploring.
Amazing views from the dome. Can't miss this one - the Basilica is beautiful and views of the city from the dome are well worth the 400 odd step climb!

Worth every forint!. Cost 200ft to go in the cathedral and 500ft to climb to the roof which was ridiculously cheap for the fantastic sights you could see. The inside of the basilica is beautiful and the view from the roof is great, as many of the otherviewsin Budapest are from the Buda side whereas this one was looking the other way. Lots of stairs though so take the lift unless you are particularly fit,

A must visit, both inside and out. Attended a sung Mass here on Sunday morning and found it prayerful in this magnificent building. Our first time to visit since the restoration was completed and we were very impressed. Apart from the beauty of the building itself, the streetscaping of the pedestrian area right down to the river has give the basilica the approach it deserves
Visit to St Stephen's Basilica. very historical and interesting to walk around. Brilliant view of city from the dome. 332 steps but a lift if you don't have energy to climb.

Gorgeous Church. The ceilings, murals and many statues top off a lovely church which despite the many tourists manages to retain a peaceful atmosphere, where you can sit and admire the art, and pray.
Don't miss it - you can even see the mummified right hand of Stephen, or Istvan to give hime his local name.
beautiful. make sure you hear mass in the evening....church will be lighted and of course you have to say thank you in your prayers for being given the chance to see budapest!!!!!
A must see. Very ornate and wonderful ceilings and dome. A small donation is requested at entrance 200HUF pp.
Stunning St Stephens. An incredible wealth of beauty all contained within this one stunning Basilica ... don't miss a visit
what a view. apart from the great view from the tower which you can get to by 300 steps or a lift the actual bascilica is unbelievable

Stunning!. In one word, absolutely stunning. The roofs of buildings in Budapest are highly ornamental and make for fantastic viewing and photographs.While we were there we witnessed a choir singing in Latin, which was a whole new experience to me and felt incredibly special. I'm not religious but this place feels very spiritual.There's loads of bars/cafes in the surrounding area which make it a good place to trek to.

A beautiful example, similar to the like of churches found in Rome.. Beautiful and ornate inside the building, but if you don't mind heights pay the small fee to go up to the balcony around the dome to see a panoramic view of the city.

A beautiful church..... St Stephen's Basilica is the most important church in Budapest. I enjoyed the frescos and altars very much. Pipe organs are of special interests to me and I found the cathedral had a very nice set. Check out the cupola as the light shines through...it is beautiful....

Spectacular Basilica. We actually decided to time our visit with attending Mass - and it was a great experience. Beautiful interior and great to see it full of life and song vs admiring it solely as tourists. Beautiful interior!
302 Steps. Worthwhile climbing every one to take in the views from the very top and the Basilica itself is a beautifull church.

BEAUTIFUL CHURCH. Beautiful church, well worth going to.We attended a classical concert there at night , which was worth going to.If you do make sure you wrap up, as even though it was warm outside it was very cold when sitting for a while in the church !!We were there in March.
Fabulous. This is definatley worth a visit only cost 200huf. fantastic architecture and decor inside amazing
Very impressive. Very beautiful cathedral, liked it a lot and definitely recommend for a visit

Beautiful Basilica. St. Stephen's is one our favorite sites in Budapest. The beauty and architecture is breath taking. Do not miss St. Stephens when you visit Budapest.
Elbert48
Go to the Heavens. Take the time and spend the little bit it takes and go to the panorama deck to enjoy the beauty of Pest.
Great concert. My wife and I saw a great organ concert! It was very nice experience! Must see!

Must visit. A stroll round the adjacent pedestrian area is a must, especially on a warm summer evening, and if you're there, you you might as well step inside the Basillica. It's not superb, but it's nonetheless impressive enough.
Amazing. Very beautiful architecture, and we sat on the steps listening to a lovely choir singing

Divine atmosphere. I visited St Stephen's Basilica the second day of my visit to Budapest. You should read a little more about St Stephens's life and his contributions to christianity, before you visit the basilica. It is a wonderful place, located in the very heart of Pest. The inside of the basilica is painted, from side walls, up to the ceiling. You can also use the opportunity so as to sit on one on the benches and pray for a while. It will help.
Magnificent. Wonderful magnificent building go top of the tower for a beautiful sight

St Stephen's. This is the largest church in Budapest holding 8500 seats. When you get there, go inside. The cost in Feb 2012 was 200 Forint which is about $1 US/Cdn.and I suspect this small fee is just to help with the upkeep of the building. You'll be amazed; it's breathtaking.
Great Cathedral. Cost 1 euro to go through. Very ornate. Would recommend.

Beautiful to view and great for photographers. This is a lovely place, so beautiful. You can get the lift to the top so don't think you have to walk. The views over the river are really nice. a lot of buildings have been cleaned recently and look very new.
Amazing. No matter your religion, this building is absolutely AMAZING! From the achtecture to the images. Really worth it.
Beautiful.. I didn't go inside, but what a beautiful place to walk around on a sunny day.
Amazing architecture.. I dont know what was more spectacular St Stephens by day or St Stephens by night.
Very nice.. Its amazing. I reccomend taking the free walking tour that meets in Deak Square. They will taje you here and tell you all about it.
Aesthetic building. This is one of the most beautiful cathedrals we've seen in Europe because of its proportions. And there is lovely work on the pavement stones by the entry.
basilica. Wonderful building dominating Budapest. Just to sit on the steps and people watch is an experience

Pay for the ticket to climb the stairs to the top of the dome. Most people, it seems go to the Bazilika and are content to take in the beauty of the inside. And, make no mistake it is breathtaking. But the real treat is paying the few hundred forint and climbing the stairs to the top of the dome. The views are some of the most unique in Budapest since the other elevated points are in Buda and look back toward Pest.
View over the city. Amazing view fron the panorama tower! Very impressive church from the inside.

Enjoyed a concert in this beautiful venue. We are a family of 2 adults and 3 children, aged 11, 9 and 6. We visited Budapest in February, which is outside the usual tourist season as it is still cold, but there are still lots of lovely things to do in Budapest, and it isn't crowded. One of the things we chose to do was go to an evening concert in the Basilica. It is a lovely venue and the acoustics are very good. There wasn't a big crowd, but this made it better. We bought 'C' tickets but found that although we were quite distant from the musicians, we could hear and see them well. The only thing we noted that it was cold, and we were glad we had wrapped up warmly. The concert lasted just long enough for the children to enjoy it without getting restless, so we all enjoyed it.

A stunning site - but its not free!. The Bascilica is really a stunning site with a grand exterior and a beautifully decorated interior. It is set in a fairly quiet square surrounded by a few cafes and shops with a direct walk to the chain bridge. In most tour books and signs at the Bascilica it is stated that this is a free attraction however this isnt actually true. There is a required donation of 200HUF which you have to pay and they actually have someone on the door stopping you from going in if you dont donate. Now ofcourse this really isnt a lot of money to part with....its just the principle! Worth a visit though
need to pay twice. We took the 299 steps to the panorama area but would have had to pay again to visit the church
Awesome but staff need a shake.. Quite stunning building inside and out.Staff are not pleasant at all.
Must see this. The history of the building and the interior are something you have to see on a trip to the city.

Wonderful. wonderful architecture, especially inside, free entrance but you shoudn't just give a donation : 2 euros in a box. it was amazing to see the Holy Right Hand of St Stephen King, which remained with skin and nails, intact. It is worth visting this place, which is also a good inspirating place for painters.

Beautiful. Beautiful building, well worth a look. Also - his mumified hand in kept in one of the rooms at the back, a bit creepy but interesting. This is also a great location by which to navigate the rest of Budapest
Beautiful. The stories of what went on here during the war was incredible. A tour guide here is worth everything you would pay.
Beautiful cathedral. The interior is stunning. Lots of natural light and serene. St Stephen's hand is preserved here for viewing.

A Wonder in a City that has been through everything. I spoke with a Hungarian lady who believed that England has more spectacular religious places. If there are can someone please tell me where they are, I have been Lands End to John O'Groats :)
A few pence entrance for upkeep and an hour of joy walking round and looking at the spectacle.
Beautiful. Yes, beautiful, but the man standing at the entrance collecting entrance fee... Hm.

Wow. Few other structures are as awe inspiring as the Basilica. Classic architectures, marble, gold leaf adorned, massive in scope. For those that appreciate achitecture or just wish to appreciate mans great achievements, this is a must see spot.
A place for church architecture lovers. A very impressive Cathedral in the Pest side. Huge building with a lot of history and fantastic decoration with beautiful marbles and "vitraux"

Another beautiful church. No matter how many churches I visit, no matter how blase' I become, I still seem unable to resist going into another church - I blame my love affair for stained glass, but it's probably because you never know what you'll find.That being said, while it is a nice church, it is not memorable among European cathedrals. It is, however, free and relatively empty which is harder and harder to find. While I was not so excited about actually viewing the hand relic, it is an interesting story. The dome is particularly nice, and the light through the stained glass windows was delightful the afternoon that we were there. The inside looks extremely clean and relatively bright, not having the dark parlor sometimes found in churches due to aging.

Beautiful Basilica. Beautiful, gold encrusted Basilica, slightly ruined by the swarms of tourists taking photos. If you want a more peaceful church visit, head to some of the smaller churches round the corner; they are empty and equally magnificent.
Stunning!. Lovely and ornate church, well worth a visit and also a short walk from great restaurants and shopping. Square church, reminded me of St. John's on Malta.
OK. Nice Church, but having been to many European cities not memorable.
very ornate. The church, located in the center of Budapest is quite typical of many large old churches in Europe which makes it well worth exploring.
Grand. It's a beaiutiful grand barokk cathedral in the heart of the city
Must see. St Stephens is a beautiful church with a chequered history. Dont miss the macabre mummiied right hand of St Stephen in its own chapel..
Just lovely.. Lovely impressive basilica with gorgeous stained glass windows in the chapel. It's best caught when the tour buses are not pouring in - when it's quiet and you can contemplate life.
Big Beautiful Church. Be sure to take the guided tours to get the most from your visit
Exterior almost understated, inside WOW!. Large square to the front giving great external views. inside fully accessible and cameras are allowed.

Saint Stephen Hand can be seen in this Basilica. You may have heard that King Stephen hand was cut off and found in the battle and they have kept it. They put the hand in the glass box where it is still being seen and well preserved hand of the ancient King. Well they have kept the hand in St. Stephen Basilica but it is well hidden and you must struggle to find it. You put a coin in and it will illuminate the hand for a short time. The basilica is a big church like other church that you see around Europe
Gilded altar. It is just beautiful. The Orbán government made it possible to renovate the basilica and now it is in it splendor.

Must-see!. Simply stunning. There isn't much information or background provided, meaning your visit will most likely be a short one, but I would say this is one of the more impressive churches I have visited. Definitely worth half an hour of your time!
Worth a visit, but worth the money?. This is a beautiful church, but we thought asking for more money to see the relic was a bit much.
Lacking.. Wasn't a patch on other European Cathedrals. Lacks signage giving info on the history of the place. Very disappointing
Lovely. This is one of the best churches I've ever seen. It is huge and very beautiful from the insight and outsight.

Concert at St. Stephen's. Amazing building with huge red marble pillars. A feeling of reverence and awe upon entry. What a sound from the organ! Difficult to describe the beautifully painted high domed ceiling. It really has to be experienced to be appreciated.

A cathedral of splendid beauty. The best of Catholic tradition.. I am an Australian from Sydney, who sang bass in the Choir of St. Mary's Cathedral here in Sydney from 1978 until December 2009. The first thing I noted about St. Stephen's Cathedral was how majestic, but not overly tacky it was. I'll talk more about this later though. I have a great dedication and love of all things tradition in Catholicism, but especially music, and I am familiar with all the great music, from Gregorian chant to the great music written in the 20th century for various liturgies, including that of Zoltan Kodaly. I was present at a Solemn Sung Sunday Mass at 10 AM (?) in January, 2010 and I was astounded at how beautiful and tasteful the choir that sang that day was. If I am not mistaken, I think it was the Kodaly Missa Brevis that the choir sang. I have sung this Mass here in Sydney myself, and it is very demanding musically. The choir did a splendid job. The organ was very beautiful also, and the organist made much of the instrument's power and majesty. To the musicians in this great cathedral, I say bravo. So many Catholic cathedrals worldwide,( especially in America, ) have opted for bad music of the lowest quality. You are showing the world how beautiful the tradition of The Church is. Thank you. The building itself was majestic, but not too "Italianate" in taste, which appealed to me. The sacristan, obviously takes great pride in this building and it is impeccably clean and he himself was welcoming and friendly. The clergy were interested in listening to me when I approached them, and knew all about our Cardinal Pell from Sydney! All good things though! I particularly loved the memorial to Cardinal Mindsenzty, who suffered much at the hands of the Communist regime. The hand of St. Stephen chuffed my interest in the aesthetic and spiritual value of Christian relics, but I didn't feel a need to venerate it!A very interesting and splendid monument to the Catholics of Hungary. You have much to be proud of. Being a lover a worldwide cathedrals, yours was one at the top of my list!Brent Anthony Egan Sydney, AUSTRALIA
Mind Blowing. See for yourselves. Please go inside, dont just look around the outside.

st stephens basilica. lovely historical building, with lots of features for lovers of history and architecture. it also has a relic: the preserved 1000 yr old right hand of king stephen. lovely promenade in front of it, easily accesible on foot or by their metro. as good in the day time or at night.
Impressive from the outside, nothing special on the inside.. The mosaic of blessings in multiple languages was interesting, but otherwise ho-hum.
Grandious. Magnificant venue of numerous event having historical importance.
Great sight. The Hungarians know how to build churches. This one is big a well-preserved.
Beautiful. Stunning architecture and design. Loved seeing the hand of St Stephen.

An impressive building. This is an imposing building from the outside, and inside maintains the impression.Personally, its not to my taste: an awful lot of gold / gilt and very ornate decoration everywhere. I found it a little "tacky" that you can go and see the hand of St. Jobb, in its casket on a plinth, and for a fee, paid to the fierce lady guarding it, you can see it light up...... However, only a small donation is asked, and it would be silly not to visit if you've made the effort to visit Budapest!

beautiful church!. It said in lonely planet this wasnt worth a visit, but the church was really ornate and pretty inside, although we couldnt see st stephens hand, as this bit of the church was closed

Great way to spend an hour or so. The inside of the basilica is beautiful - great architecture and detail. There is a small donation you pay to go inside. You can also pay an additional fee to go up the tower - well worth it, because you can go onto the outside walk way and get great views over Budapest and the Danube. Definitely worth going here for about an hour.

A must see. Take your camera, inside is amazing, great windows and paintings, if your feeling fit have a walk to the top, if your not take the lift views over Budapest are some of the best you'll find
Peaceful beauty. It just requires a small donation to get into the Basilica, well worth it.Guided tours are available but just walking round yourself can be just as good.

Breathtaking Church !. We stopped by the outside of this breathtaking church during the day and at night, however at night was my favorite...it has the same feeling like the Duomo in Florence....very majestic and just beautiful.

Ornate. Certainly see where all the wealth was spent back then and interesting story of the Holy Right Hand of King Saint Stephen. In the square in front of church they had kiosks to sell homemade items and children dancing in native costumes.
Fascinating. The architecture is fascinating, the peace felt inside is mesmerising, the organ is so beautiful, would love to hear somebody playing it, the main altar is stunning
grrrrrrr. no longer free entrance to

highly suggested at Christmas time. In the centre of Pest, you will find this beautiful cathedral.Its façade looks amazing, above all, getting there from the straight street which ends in the church square.The interior is good, but maybe I couldn't appreciate it very much, because it was on Sunday, and there was the Holy celebration,. So there were too much people and tourists, attending the celebration. I can suggest, if you are interested in architecture and all this stuff, to visit it during a weekday.But the thing I loved the most was the square opposite the Cathedral, decorated for Christmas time. There were an amazing local X-Mas market all around, and small kiosks selling typical hungarian food. hot hungarian red chips with paprika are highly suggested!!!
Inspiring and comforting. I felt so at home in this basilica. I visited it several times while in Budapest.
Just Lovely. The Basicilia is a must-see in Budapest. It is absolutely stunning. the hand of St Stephen was very interesting.

Impressive Basillica. Worth going to if you have the time and it's a free entrance as well! It is very similar to other Basillica's around Europe but the building itself is still very impressive. The surrounding area as well is a very pretty part of the city with Adrassy avenue and the Danube nearby.
Stunning Work. The fully restored Basilica will have you gaping in awe at its beautiful building and the dome as well. The view from the top is worth seeing!
Historical church. It's a historical church. A small trunk with St. Stephen's hand in it stays in the middle of the church.

Beautiful basilica. The basilica was beautiful. But...I´m sorry, but I think that gift is something I want to give to someone. Not that the priest stays next to a money box on which is written gift to church, but you´re not allowed to go inside the basilica if you don´t insert CERTAIN amount of money, which they want. Thay should call it entrance fee not GIFT! I was very dissapointed!!!
Splendid. Beautiful building. You are expected to donate some money to the priest at the door. It was worth it.
Impressive. Don,t miss out - it is breathtaking what architecture make sure you go right to the top for some breath taking views

One of my favourite buildings in Budapest. The first time I went in this building I just fell in love. It's huge and has a very architectural alter with a figure of St Stephen. You can take photos with a flash, and there's plenty to snap, with statues and frescoes everywhere. Out the back is the chapel with amazing stained glass windows and the hand of St Stephen on display (you have to pay to make the casket light up), as well as flags and information. You have to visit this place while in Budapest.

Simply beautiful. I was very lucky to be invited to a wedding that started at the basilica and had the chance to enjoy the interior in all its glory. No need to say that the wedding was one of the most beautiful I've ever been to... It is simply beautiful and so grand!

I like the building when it lit. I love this building during the night time when the lights are lit. The most beautiful when it is snowing and I just stand in front of the Basilica being mesmerized by it's beauty.
Impressive. You could spend all day inside this Basilica. It's just awe-inspiring. Allow some time, and go with a guide. There is so much to see.
A beautiful basilica. The tall and beautifully decorated basillica of st. Istvan is a beautiful place and you can easily spend 30 minutes admiring it, inside out.

Stunning!. See for yourself. The ornate interior is just wonderful. It is like standing inside a jewellery box. By contrast the chapel where the mummified forearm of St Stephen is housed seems quite plain, but you can't have everything!
Recommend to visit. Amazing building with catholic atmosphere. Good condition. Big square at the front of the main entance
This is my name sake.. My parent's named me after King Steven, a noble heritage. My name is Istvan also.
Stunning!. This was just incredible outside- we didnt get a chance to go in, as there is so much to do in Budapest, but i definitely recommend it to others

lovely both on the exterior and interior.. St. Istvan’s Basilica is so beautiful..
Having decorative cupolas, marble and gilt everywhere, detailed work on arches and ceilings - really remarkable.
The Basilica is an imposing building in a very central location.
It is lovely both on the exterior and interior.
Christmas decorations was for me special gift

Breath Takeing. The St.Stefan Basilica hosts the most sacred treasure of Hungary wich is the Mummified Right Hand of St.Stefan.RIght on the top of the Basilica you will have a great view of the entire city and the acoustic is wonderfull durring the Organ Concerts.
Wonderful. Very ornate with lovely ceilings and carvings etc. Do not miss it.
Beautiful Inside and Out. This is a beautiful building. The inside could use some extra lighting.

Must-see Beautiful Basilica. The Basilica is an imposing building in a very central location. It is lovely both on the exterior and interior.I visited St. Istvan’s Basilica and spent about 45 minutes viewing this beautiful Church with its decorative cupolas, marble and gilt everywhere, detailed work on arches and ceilings - really remarkable. I took time to take in and admire the detailed work and took pictures.Christmas decorations were still evident in the Church and added to its beauty.In one of the Chapels in the Basilica, the withered right fist of the saint is kept in a beautiful silver casket with open-work so one can view the fist.

Set your expectations re: cost and schedule. A visit to St. Stephen’s Basilica is on many Budapest visitors’ list, and while some are satisfied with seeing the building from the outside, others, like me, want to experience it fully. From the TA forums, I learned that someone garbed in priestly clothing collects an entry “donation” and that one can take a lift up to the dome of the basilica to get a great view of Budapest. With the help of Donbacsi, who translated the Hungarian website for me, I knew the Sunday Mass schedule and planned on attending one of them. However, I happened to be in the area on Saturday afternoon and I inquired at the door if there was a Vigil Mass. I was told by a man garbed in a robe (I doubt he was a priest) that there was one an hour later, so I decided to enter the church and just stay there until the service. The man then pointed to the donation box and said I needed to put in 1 euro or 240 HUF. As I did not have enough forint coins, I gave him a 500-forint note, half expecting to get change back. He smiled at me, put the note in the donation box, and waved me in (and I got my answer about the change). I can see how this can be off-putting to many tourists. The man acted more like a gatekeeper than a church member whose gentle presence was there to remind you that donations are welcome but not required. Even though I knew about the entrance donation and had read many reviews on TA regarding it, I was still a bit put off by the process. This was , after all, a church, not a theme park, and while I was a tourist, I also was going to attend services. I wondered if the entry donation was collected from everybody, including those who are come to attend Mass, or only from tourists (and those who look like tourists). I never got the answer and since I got there an hour before the scheduled Mass time, I can understand how one would assume I was just a tourist come to take photos. Once inside, I noted signage to Szent Jobb Kapolna (Chapel of the Holy Right Hand) stating that it was only open during certain periods (see attached photo) and I realized I needed to return the following day if I wanted to see St. Stephen’s relic (his mummified right hand). I inquired of another similarly garbed man what time the dome was open for access, as I didn’t see any signage for it. He didn’t seem to speak much English, and only said it was “closed.” I took that to mean that, like the chapel, it was closed for the day and given that it was already 5 p.m. and dark outside, I wasn’t surprised that they would close the dome. The Vigil Mass was in Hungarian and lasted the usual hour, but given that there were very few people there (only the front pews were full), there wasn’t much heat to go around, and I was feeling chilled halfway through. Because I really wanted to see the relic and go up to the dome, I returned to St. Stephen’s the following morning (Sunday). I arrived halfway through the Mass and another 240 HUF was collected from me at the door. I gave him all the coins I had and he laid them out next to the donation box and counted them to make sure I had a) at least 240 HUF, and b) I wasn’t trying to slip in other currencies. Again, this process showed how this was less of a “donation” and more of an entrance fee. Entrance to Szent Jobb Kapolna was closed off until after the Mass ended and the congregation dispersed. To get to the chapel, one enters through a wood and glass door in what looks like a confessional box. This is to the left hallway of the main altar (if facing the altar). The door leads to a short hallway, and another wooden door. Through that door, one goes up a few steps and down another short hallway (you’ll see an oversized rosary in a glass case to the left). The door at the end of the hallway is the door to the chapel. When you enter, you’ll see a few pews and at the front of the room is where the relic is kept (you’ll recognize the case it is housed in from the picture on the signage). There is another man garbed similarly as the main entrance gatekeeper standing by a sign that states that it will cost two 100-forint coins to light up the relic for two minutes. Otherwise, all one can sees is ornamental glass case. As I had given all my forint coins at the main entrance, and I didn’t have any small bills on me, I had to forgo seeing the relic. The few other people who were also in the chapel chose to do the same thing. I left after a short while. Fortunately, there are posters inside the chapel that tells the story of the relic as well as pictures of what it looks like, so that assuaged some of my disappointment. Outside the chapel, I sought out another of those church workers to inquire about the dome. I was told again that it was closed, so I asked if it was closed for the day or if it was closed for the winter. Again, with limited English, he repeated, “Is closed.” So that’s how my St. Stephen’s Basilica experience ended. I didn’t purchase a religious item from the shop outside to get it blessed at the side door (another tip from Donbacsi off the TA forum), as at that point, I just wasn’t feeling up for it. I share this rather lengthy review not to discourage anyone from visiting St. Stephen’s, but to provide guidance to others based on my experience. In summary:- If you are interested in getting information on the Mass schedule, there is a website, but it is only in Hungarian: www. http://bazilika.biz/. If you click on "Napter" ("Day Map" or calender) you will see the small mass is at 8:30, the "Latin" mass is at 10:00 and the big Hungarian mass is at 12:00. (Thanks, Donbacsi)-Costs you should be aware of:  --- Cost to enter the basilica: 250 HUF or 1 Euro coin (Bills considered as entire donation; no change given) --- Cost to enter Szent Jobb Kapolna (Chapel of the Holy Right Hand): Free --- Cost to light up the relic for two minutes so one can take photographs: two 100-forint coins --- Cost to go up to the dome: Unknown (it was unavailable while I was there), but a previous TA review (May 2011) indicated that only euros were accepted
St Stephens. Great sights both inside and out. Pay the price to go to the top and see over the city.

Beautiful history. A beautiful building from the outside only bettered by going inside. Christmas was still in evidence when I visited which added to the beauty and the entrance cost is so low you just feel its right to put more in the box.
Lovely inside. Although lovely on the inside, be aware that a priest stands outside and hovers over you to make sure you put a donation in his box! A little bit suspicious if you ask me....
Out of question! must to visit!. Sooooo beautiful! Recently renovated, and the whole area is coming up very fast, new restaurants, hotels and places to visit all around, one of the very favourites.

Beautiful church. St Stephen's is a beautiful place - high domes, a serene atmosphere, and the hand of a saint, to boot! It is centrally located, looking out over a large courtyard in the center of a lot of shops and restaurants.
awesome building. wonderful church....the roof is beautiful and the view is awesome...
ABC. A magnificant building worthy of a visit, and close to the centre for shopping etc
You could be in Italy!. Another incredible holy site the seat of Christianity & Catholicism in Hungary.

Mummified hand?. amazing lead-light work, massive ceilings and small eves for praying. work of art in an amazing location.
If you can, make your approach from a few streets back on the river side and come straight on to the Basilica to get the best views!
Another beautiful chruch!. It is so beautiful. I wished that I could listen to its gospel music while I was there. It would be an awesome place to attend a Sunday mass...so holy!
Beautiful interior.. The interior was not only beautiful but all the art and artifacts show just how much loved this Basilica is by the people of Budapest.
Big and boring. Yet another Basilica interesting but not impressive, not really a must if you have already seen other Basilicas.

One basilica to see. Entrance costs one euro (200 HUF) it is actually for donation.
You can see the relic (right hand of St Stephen).
They organize concert

Free but not that free. It is a free site to visit actually, but strangely a father is standing asking for donation with a minimum of 20 Hungarian Forint, even our local guide say it is weird. Inside the basilica it is so grand and beautiful, worth more than the minimum donation anyway.

Must see sight for any visitor to Budapest. Stunning Cathedral on the Pest side, beautiful interior, some very interesting and unusual artefacts, especially the hand, wonderful views and a great stopping place for peace and quiet and a quiet pray as well.
overwhelmingly ornate. a full-on catholic church interior, the most rich & ornate I have ever seen!

Neo-Classic cathedral. Being the most important church building in Hungary (so I'm told) the building itself is not terribly interesting. Completed around 1900 it is built in a neo classical style and lacks originality. The Matyas church on the Buda side is much more interesting historically.
Just a fantastic and beautiful building. Especially lit up at night! We went to a concert after purchasing tickets on the street and it was superb!
A beautiful building.. It is worth the visit to this beautiful church. I went to the tourist organ recital which was decent.

Great architecture. we only saw the outside but it was beautiful. It is two blocks in from the mouth of the train bridge on the non castle district side. Worth seeing. For christmas there were markets and an ice skating rink parked directly in front of it.
St. Stephen's Basilica,. Impressive interior, richly decorated, beautiful stained-glass windows. Interesting chapel with the relics of St. Stephen's right hand.

Must see - especially for those not drawn to churches!. Very beautiful building, in impeccable condition, wonderfully restored. Interesting even for non believers, as basilica is welcoming warm and beautifully lit. One wants to linger hours... Xavier Thoma

Impressive. This church is impressive. A lot of concerts are inside. If you like just to visit please check the time schedule usually is opened till 19.30 but when there are concerts the schedule may change accordingly.

Beautiful church. We keep Christmas devotional d 25.12 at 18.00 in this large beautiful church. It was an incredibly beautiful church and worship. It lasted 1 hour. Outside the church there was a Christmas market. There were stalls selling hot drinks, Hungarian national dishes and delicacies. Square was lit up with fairy lights on trees. It was beautiful in the dark and cold.After the service, people gather at the stalls and got heat by consuming the hot food and drink. Old and young, rich and poor. It was nice and a good atmosphere.

The right fist and the left foot. It is an impressive building. To get into you have to give a donation of 1Euro and in the Chapel you can see the fist of St.Stephen. Lights are often turned off but it is one of the most important places in the city and you have to go.
An opportunity for photos. Nice church, nice Christmas market right in front of it. Can be seen from almost everywhere. Worth to pay a visit.
Stunning church!. Don't miss this stunning Budapest sight! Located in city center.
Take the lift and admire wonderful Budapest from the top of the cathedral..... The perfect way to have a great view on the architectural highlights of the city

Breathtaking - amazingly beautiful everywhere you look. One of the most breathtaking cathedrals I've ever seen. The walls and the ceilings are covered in paintings and statues accented with gold. When in Budapest, do not miss St Stephen's!

Atmospheric and beautiful. Small donation is requested on entry but it is not compulsory. Most other things in Budapest require a ticket except Parliament which is free for EU passport holders. The mummified hand of St. Stephen is just a brown bit of stuff that looks like wood in a casket - not much to see but it is an important symbol for Hungarians.

Remember, it is free!. When I and my husband got in the church, there was a man dressed as a catholic priest (he might have been a priest I can't say for sure) in the entrance, with a donation box, asking for a "donation for the poor". We put 1 euro in the box and he said "You are 2 you have to put more money in the box". When we reminded him that this was a donation and not a ticket, he just said "ok,ok, get in". I must say I didn't like this at all.The church is beautiful with marble statues of King Istvan (Stephen-the first christian king of Hungary) and his brother. You can spend some time in there if you like. If you don't, just get out and take a long walk along Adrassy st, a beautiful street just 200 meters far from the church.
Not to miss. This should not be missed. It is not a disappointment and only a short walk form the centre square

An Imposing Beauty. The basilica makes an incredible impression on you especially in the right lighting (when the sun sets against its walls, for example, or when the ambient lighting illuminates it at night). At risk of sounding overly poetic, this building has always functioned as a sort of mystical center to my explorations of Pest. Each time I return I have a different experience. Besides, you have a wonderful array of cafes around the area where you can have a drink or meal and take in the incredible surroundings. A great place to spend a relaxing afternoon.
AMAZING. You have to go and have a look around if you are in Budapest. It only takes a minute and even if churches are not your thing you will be amazed.
A must see when in Budapest. Magnificent architecture and impressive acoustics.

Very lovely neo-classical church. In addition to the amazing interior the church also includes the mummified hand of St Stephen, whom it is named after. The light show projected on the front of the church during Christmas was also lovely.
St Stephen's Basilica. Walking around but not in the Basilica. Very impressive art work on the outside of the church.
Concert. Very moving string quartet played brilliant accoustics and I cried!
Splendid. The Cathedral is a beatiful building, but one should go to the top for magnificent 360) panorama's
Imposing. The basilica is a large structure and the inside and outside don't have the excessive gilt that many do. Liked it and the surrounding neighbrhood better at night.
Beautiful building. Worth the visit, christmass markets outside the front with lovely hot wine too
fantastic experience. you have to see this.renovated basillica not far way fron pomo d oro restaurant
Spectacular church. Centrally located, beautiful and large church. Check out the classical concerts.

Nice visit. The basilicas is very nice, entrance tiket is cheep.After visiting the bottom part remember to go on the left side and see the mummified hand of the sanit then some stairs take you up to the middle floor where from some balconies you can get a good view of the church again.When we visited it the climb up the tower was closed.Again, as I said in general about the castle hill do not eat there, walk down and look for restaurants near the Danube.

Beautiful - evening concert a must. I was in Budapest for a short weekend break with a girlfriend. We visited in the day (note services take place as normal on a Sunday from around 11am) - the Basilicata is beautiful and the story behind its contruction and architechture is fascinating. We came back in the evening to experience a classical concert (around €17) - not something I normally do, but the acoustics were incredible. Then explored the Christmas market outside, which was very picturesque. I would rate this as a highlight of my weekend.
Awesome. The architecture is unbelievable. There was a service on at the time we were there and it was very moving.
Amazing Historic Church. Just awe inspring to walk inside and see the history this church has. Almost impossible to convey in a TA review but if you are there GO.

Beautiful Basilica with an interesting twist. St. Stephen (Szent Istvan) was the first king of Hungary and brought Christianity to the country. He is one of the favorite Hungarian kings and it shows in this basilica. The main statue in the church behind the alter is St. Stephen and the basilica also contains his mummified right hand. Navigate to a side room in the back of the basilica to see this creepy but kind of fascinating attraction. For 200 HUF you can light up the area where the hand is resting for an even better look. We visited in December and there seemed to be almost nightly concerts at this beautiful church. There was also a small and beautiful Christmas market in the square outside.

impressive landmark. The huge dome of St Stephen's is visible from most parts of Budapest. They have a Christmas market there in November/December too. The inside is pretty impressive but you need to visit on a bright day to see it at it's best.
Very Impressive. Very impressive bazilika in its own well restored area. Beautiful views from the top of the dome.

Not to be missed. Described as the most important church in the city, it soon became obvious why. Wonderful artworkand carvings almsot from floor to ceiling and the various side chapels all have their one stories. Most moving was the Chapel of The Holy Right Hand, not to be missed. Best of all, the visitors all seemed to realise what a Holy place this is and behaved accordingly

Not an Actual Basilica. We learned from our walking tour guides that this grand, gorgeous building is not actually a basilica, but was 'declared' such by a visiting pope. Still, a stunning landmark in a beautiful city.

One of the nicest Churches I've seen!. Seen many over the last few years in my european travels and have to say this one rates highly. It's a very nice building both outside and inside. You have to make a ''donation'' to enter, albeit it wasn't much (250 HUF each).It is a very well maintained building and worth the visit if you're in Budapest.

Not so big as I tought, but still a good spot to take pictures. At first I tought that it would be a huge Basilica.. But once in front I was not so amazed... of course it is beautiful.. but still I saw bigger and greater one already.. But still a good place for pictures !

So much to look at! it is a must in Budapest.. This has to be the most delicate and detail loaded monument I have ever seen. At the same time it is elegant and light. You need a few hours to enjoy that place.The quality of the marble floors is second to none, the craftsmanship is unbelievable.

Beautiful piece of architecture. A gorgeous building both inside and out. Take some time to walk through it. Close to lots of other great places to see. Can be busy so try to go during less popular times of the day.
wow. Basilica was something i didnt expect! it was just breathtaking beauty!
another cathedral. The inside is quite dark, but lovely. It is interesting if you're in the area, but not worth a special trip. For us it was a nice place to warm up a bit on a cold day.
Really beautiful. Loved this place came back twice, a great Italian restaurant down from it too.
As churches go, this is a good one. I've seen a lot of European churches, and honestly they are all the same after a while. If you go to Sunday mass it's free.
Fascinating.. This didn't feel too much like a holy place although there was a lot of historical information and a museum. A huge building with many renovated parts.

A beautiful building, shame about the staff. I love going in to churches, as the reflect a lot of the history of the place. St Stephens somehow exudes a grandeur not normally associated with religious belief. I was offended by the demand to make a donation before being allowed to enter the church. The also stipulate the minimum doatation you should make. Not very God like!!
Gorgeous. The inside of this Basilica was beautiful! So grand. Worth the 200 florint "donation."

"best of" Classical music Concert. For a small entrance fee you get to enjoy the Basilica accompanied by a classic concert. This is probably not a year around experience, but if you go there in the winter season it's most definitely recommended!The Concert will take you through some of our time's most famous composers lasting an hour or so.The Basillica is in a prestine condition and a magnificent sight.
Not to be Missed. Beautiful Basilica to see. Is illuminated at night and many wonderful restaurants and cafe's in the nearby area.

Gorgeous! Be sure to go to the tower. The view from the top was excellent, and as it is a dome, you get a 360 degree view. The mummified hand deal is kind of creepy, especially when the clergy encourage you to drop in coins to light it up.
Great view. We visited when it was mass, so we could not really look around in the basilica. We were however able to climb the tower, which was really nice with beautiful views of Budapest.

Unforgettable. This was un-real. We saw it at night. Unforgettable. Someone was practicing on the organ while we were there. What a treat. This is a most spectacular site. Went back to see it and the surrounding area by day. Yes....do it!!!

Breathtaking!. I would highly suggest going to see the Basilica at dusk and to approach it from the river, looking down the long promenade leading to the Basilica...this will take your breath away.It will probably be closed late but the lighting and shadows create an atmosphere one can revel in for hours.A visit to Budapest would not be complete without a visit to the Basilica!

Angelic Choir on most Sundays. Of course, the neo-Romanesque Basilica itself is an art piece. However, most Sundays at 10 AM, you can participate at Mass while the excellent choir performs Sacred Music of Mozart, Liszt, and other masters. You can also climb to the tower for a wonderful panoramic view of Budapest.

Oppressive. Amazing architecture from the outside. Inside was very dimly lit and oppressive.Yes, it was beautiful, but didnt feel uplifted !Was stung for money as soon as we got to the steps at the entrance.... then again pounced on by a grovelling priest. Would have gone to see St.Stephens mumified hand, but could see another priest lurking in the shaddows..... and this was all meant to be free !!
Lovely Church. Beautiful church with spectacular views from the top

very good. in winter, you can't go up for a nice view over Budapest and you have to donate a gift when you enter. After 16u you cannot visit the right hand anymore. Nice basilica, very beautiful and well maintainted.
A beauty!. Very nice architecture! The inside is beautiful! we loved it! The location is quite good.
Great views of the city. The structure itself is a sight to be seen but the views of the city are an added bonus.
Must see. Basilica is in a very good condition, with solemnity outside and vividness inside. So beautiful to take nice photos ))
Beautiful. Both outside and inside! Classical music concerts can be attended inside on a regular basis. Very pleasant experience in such a special setting
St Stephens Basillica. This is a must see.. Absolutely gorgeous art and the decor is outstanding... Amazing to see this magnificent building, reminded me on the Doges palace in Venice
Incredibly beautiful. We had a chance to go in during mass. It was amazing! Worth the donation to go inside.
Concert time. went to a concert and sat under the main dome. Mistake! The acoustic gave so much echo. Sit nearer the musicians, who were very good.

Beautiful Church. We visited this church as from the outside it looks impressive and when you go inside it is mind blowingly beautiful.There is also the mumified hand of St stephen himself in one of the side rooms.A little bit macabre but the hungarians regard it as religious shrine.I would highly recommend you to visit this church and it will leave a good impression on you

Visit and enjoy. Enjoy an Concert, normaly offered in several days during the week. Information could be found throughout The City, often near Tram stations. Worth visiting, Check Out whats on The playlist
Stunning. Just wonderful? the building inside is truly wonderful and not quite what you expect from outside
Budapest Nov 2011. Beautiful building and can take the stairs to the top which gives excellent views of Budapest.

Beautiful Church - awesome views". My friend & I visited St Stephen's on our first day in Budapest. The church was beautiful but the views from the top of the tower were AWESOME!! A must see when you are in that beautiful city.
Amazing place. Amazing place, very well maintained and looks very interesting place to see.

Well worth the visit. I was lucky to catch an orchestra practicing in the main section. A treat. I could not find St Stephen's hand or any signs indicating where it was in the building. You can easily see the most of the building in a short time.
Voluptuous. Richly decorated and colourful interior. Take the opportunity to climb the 65 metres to the balcony around the roof with great views of the city.
Can compare to Roma. This is an exellent and stunning church. There is a lift to a panorama-view for a little extra cost.

Incredible. The interior of St. Stephen's is spectacular. It was actually one of my favorite religious buildings I visited in Europe. It's not completely necessary to climb the tower, though, since the view it's really of much.

A Budapest Icon. Certainly a trip to Budapest would not be complete without a visit to St. Stephen's Basilica. It is somewhat similar to St. Paul's in London. Built in a neoclassical style. It is 315 feet high and containts a reliquary with the preserved right hand of King Stephen. It is Hungarian Catholicism's holiest relic. The square is a good place to relax with cup of coffee with a view. A fine photo op. Not to be missed.
Beautiful Basilica. With a personal guide we learned about St Stephen and his great work in Hungary.
Impressive. The St Paul's of Budapest (although Catholic of course).

Lovely. We went after sundown and saw the Basilica in a tungsten glow. Looked quite impressive. As you walk down the street next to the Gresham Palace you see the imposing structure straight ahead between the buildings on the road. As you approach it you see that the road opens out into a square and the Basilica sits at the end of it. We reached there at the turn of the hour and heard the church bells. Sounded lovely. We sat in a coffee shop on the square and sipped on hot cappuccinos while a chilly wind blew and did loads of people watching!

Amazing place. This place is really amazing. You have to see this being in Budapest. It is beautiful and perfect in every detail. This Roman Catholic basilica is named in honour of Stephen, the first King of Hungary (c 975–1038), whose mummified fist is housed in the reliquary.Please read about the history about this place before and pay attention to the height of this. It is 96 meters high- the same like Parliament. Because of Hungary history.
Must do!!!. The Friday night concert was enchanting. We wouldn't have missed this for the world.
Fabulous views. climb is not as bad as St Peter's in Rome but no signs about cardiac conditions. elevator to the viewing gallery/platform. Quite reasonable cost with the Budapest card.

St. Stephen's is a Neo-Classical Monument. St Stephen's Basilica is a massive late 19th Century Catholic Church that looks like it is from centuries earlier. On the inside there are baroque frescoes and a relic, the hand of St. Stephen, that looks like something from a carnival side show. We did not pay the fee to enter as we were there for Mass. The Church itself is huge and impressive.

Donation mandatory. It's a beautiful church, ant the 360 degrees view over Budapest from the tower is absolutely breathtaking. You need to pay 2 times, once to go up into the tower ( you can do so with the elevator or climbing the spiral staircase) - the fee was 500 FT per person- and the second time when you enter the church 200FT per person. My problem with the second fee is that it is called a donation, and in my opinion a donation is something that you do voluntarily. When it is mandatory like in this case they should call it entrance fee. I wonder if they charge it for the people who like to go there and pray?
Beautiful. Lovely 18th century Baroque church with great artwork. Interesting history. ou've got to see the hand.

A birds eye view!. Not only is the interior of this beautiful cathedral amazing, the view from the top is incredible. Absolutely buy the ticket and walk up the winding staircase to the top to look out over the city. A great way to orient yourself, and get up close and personal with the church spires of the city.

You are forced to make a donation, but it is worth. In my first attempt to visit the Basilica I´ve got really upset when I was been tld that a donation was mandatory to enter.My wife convinced me to go back next day, this time for an organ concert.The bulding is beautiful, ornaments are not TOO much, the concert was excellent.....it is worth a visit.
Worth a visit!. A stone throw from our hotel, this Basilica was like a tardis, albeit a very large tardis. Spectacular once you are on the inside...
beautiful. most ornate church we have ever been in - breathtaking.

Amazing!. i just loved the fact that we access to the main tower! its an excellent view, and i think they were still working on arranging a small expo on the way up, which i think a tourist will enjoy! very well kept and the lady that was selling the tickets was nice and had a good understanding of English !

Look better on the inside. The basiilica is our 3rd visiit over ten years, road works and scaffold around the area spoil the look and feel of it, BUT when you go inside after paying security guards making sure a site o be seen fantastic ceilings and a feeling of wealth
Beautiful Building. Considering it's only 100 years old it looks very ancient

very nice church. The church was very nice. When we came in we saw that we had to pay a small amount to go in(100fr i think). We refused to pay and started leaving when the man in the door said we could go for free because of the children. I find the fact of paing to go in a church totally unaceptable. When we were inside we gladlly paid 100 fr for the cantle.
tower hike worth a trip. one of the most spectacular churches i have been too. view from the tower is impressive.mumified hand slightly creepy
Elegant. Part of the heritage of the city, this church is graceful and elegant and worth a visit as you wander through this beautiful city.

Wow... What a view!. We visited the Basilica in September 2011, Firstly we entered the church itself, you do have to pay, but it is such a small amount and we felt we would gladly pay to help the upkeep of such a wonderful Basilica. It truly is magnificent inside, beautiful ceilings and artwork all around, a very special place. We also decided to climb the stairs to the top of the Basilica, which we paid again for (very little money) we climbed all of the steps up a narrow spiral staircase, and stumbled out at the top only to have our breath taken away even more at the amazing views! You can walk round the entire dome for a 360 degree view of the city, it is so worth it, and I think we appreciated it more having climbed the stairs all the way to the top. The sculptures around the lower part of the Basilica are beautiful and make great photographs. We thoroughly enjoyed our vist, one of the best parts of our trip!
Very Impressive. The Basilica is very impressive, however it was partially closed for a wedding the day we attended.
St. Stephens. Internal decoration unbelievable. Wonderful building.
Concert at St Stephen's. Went to an early evening concert with a very talented organist, flutist and operatic bass. Very enjoyable, quality entertainment at a fair price
Very nice but why pay to visit a church?. The church has great architecture. However entry to the church is chargeable. I strongly disklike that.

Spectacular Sanctuary - The Heart of Budapest. Having been in churches and basilica's throughout Europe, I never thought that visiting St. Stephen's Basilica would be anything out of the ordinary. Was I in for a surprise. Entering the Basilica took my breath away. It is spectacular in its beauty and artistry. Unlike the hoards that have Disneyfied Sacre Couer, St. Stephen's remains a quiet religious sanctuary. Take either the stairs or the elevator to the roof...the view of Budapest is spectacular.

Neo Renaissance Grandure. After years of neglect, this magnificent Basillica was refurbished and restored to it's original grandure. Especially enjoyed the concert we attended in the evening. Mozart and the acoustics were mutually thrilling.

Simply stunning.. We decided to visit the Basilica on the last day of our holiday in Budapest, and we were not disappointed. An impressive looking building that towers over the square it is located on. It has many intricate carvings and beautiful stonework. Budapest in general is blessed with stunning buildings, with a wide variety of architectuaral styles, though gothic does seem to be the most prominent! We paid the small fee of 1500 HUF to go up to the top of the Basilica and take in the view. Firstly you have to walk up a very large flight of stairs (stone, spiral stairway, would not recommend for the faint hearted or vertigo sufferers), which brings you into a large, sparsely decorated room. Then it's a lift almost to the top, then a few more stairs. The view is incredible. You can see almost the whole of Budapest, and as you can walk all around the top there is plenty to see! It gives a lovely view on the square below, which has a little market open on it every day selling local crafts and snacks (sadly we decided not to sample the "rooster testicle" they had on offer!). We spent a good 30-45 minutes up there walking around, taking in the view and admiring the craftmanship of the building itself. Afterwards we went into the basilica itself, there is no fee but they do have a donation box. I'm not a religious person but I have an appreciation for history and I love religious buildings, because they are usually beautifully decorated and crafted. I was not disappointed. The inside is unbelieveable. The dome is intricrately decorated, as is the rest of it really. It is adorned with statues and gold. Every little detail from floor to ceiling is amazing, and the place is well taken care of and very clean. Highly recommend a visit!
Awesome views. Such a nice place to go. We got the hill tram up there and were in awe of such a pretty place.
Do Not Miss. Magnificent site. One of the most beautiful Basillica's I have ever seen. Rivals those of Rome.

beautiful outside , beautiful inside. I did not expect anything special from a Basilica, but it was amaizing. It is beautiful all around from the outside and it is really worth the time to go inside and look around. You can also walk up to the top to see the views. Do not miss it!

St Stephen's Basilica. The tower is well worth climbing - the stairs - nice wide steps and not too difficult - fabulous views over the city. Try and get to an organ recital or one of the many concerts. What an atmosphere.
Beautiful place to vist. Came across St Stephen's by accident but so glad I did.The place was so beautiful (had a stiff neck from constant looking up)Well worth the visit.
Beautiful church. We're Jewish, but the relic of St Stephen's hand in the smaller chapel is fascinating, especialy for kids.

Worth visiting. An attractive cathedral but not that impressive when compared to the many wonderful cathedrals gracing main cities in Europe. Tickets for a concert in the cathedral were for sale when we visited, very expensive we thought as the price was identical to a ticket to the opera.

Beautiful Church with Interesting Square in front. This is a magnificant church located not far from the Chain Bridge that crosses the Danube. When I was there . . . on a Sunday . . . . . the square in front was filled with various vendors and there were young men and women performing and dancing.
Beautiful Cathedral. Well worth a visit, although visitors are restricted to certain areas.

Amazing views from the tower!. Take the lift up to the top of the tower - we climbed it - out of breath and vertigo! But the views from the top are fantastic - 360 degrees view of Budapest, the Danube and the surrounding countryside.
nice. It is a nice and impressive basica with very special lights falling in

amazing view from Dome. Just beautiful. Church itself stunning and so worth the 60p suggested donation (they can't give change, and we didn't have any small coins, having only just landed, so we gave £3 for 2 of us and the bloke nearly fainted from gratitude). But definitely make the trip up to the dome - it's a really gorgeous view out over the whole Pest side, the river and the Buda side, and a lovely way to start your trip as you can really get your bearings. Costs the same to take the lift or the stairs £1.50)
Magnificent. Tours are available, just to stand in the square and look at it is overwhelming.
Concert in St. Stephens. We joined a concert with a mix of classic music and it was a wonderful experience.The building is beautiful both outside and inside.

Beautiful. Worth a look! Stunning architecture.. An utterly beautiful piece of architecture, amazing carving, statues and the view from the viewing platform is amazing, the walk up however is not for the faint hearted, however you won't be disappointed (there is a lift too) the hand of st Stephen was a tad on the odd side, overall very good

Beautiful. I am not religious at all but this is stunning inside....Not to be missed. if you wish to vist the tower and have beautiful views over Budapest there is an elevator to take you up if you cant manage the stairs...200 Huf as a donation, and 500 Huf to get up the tower.. Worth it tho.

Beautiful church and an excellent concert. We visited the church for an evening concert and was that impressed with the interior that we visited the following day. Our classical concert, including the wonderful playing of the church organ was very enjoyable, although the padding on the pews was a little too thin for our liking. There wasn't a fee for going into thye church with our guide, although he did ask for any small contribution to help with the upkeep of the church, whihc we did not regret paying and hope these contributions allow the chucrh to be maintained for mnay more years and visitor's delights in the future.
Beautiful!. Worth a look! It is absoultely beautiful! Stunning architecture. The intricacy of the carvings in the wood and paintings in the cupola are exquisite!

Amazing Basilica.. Really beautiful Basilica saw it inside during the day and buy night from the outisde.
They have concerts as well. At night it's just stunning.

Stunning interiors. When we saw the outside of the basilica we weren't impressed at all. For entering you are ask to give 200 hungarian florins (less than an euro) as a donative for maintaining the building. But it worths it because the interiors are awesome, the coupule shining with golden decorations... really, this building, the Parliament and Mathias Church are the best of Budapest. The only downside was that in order to see the "hand" of St. Stephen illuminated you have to put some coins in a machine, it seemed a bit wrong to us, but in fact it had no interest at all.

beatiful touristic church. This church is build in the center of Budapest in a very beatiful square. We have been here 3 years ago and we ware very happy. Now there was someone at the main entrance who was require 1 euro donation for the church!!! Outside there in a machine that gives you with money of cource, a coin with the picture of st. stephens basilica. Be cαareful, you should have the required fiorins exactly, nowone wants to change a big paper money......i counted believe it

A Stunning Basillica. The basiillica was built in 1851 and was only a 2 minute walk from our hotel which was on the Danube. It is free to get in although a donation is expected and we were happy to contribute. The inside is a profusion of reddish marble and gold and more ornate than most churches I have visited in the UK, the dome was impressive also.In a side chapel in a glass case supposedly holds the hand of St Stephen and for a small fee you can pay to have it lit up which I found bizarre.It is worth taking the lift or for those of you who are brave can take the stairs up to the bell tower and viewing platform as there are some very impressive views of Budapest. Well worth visiting!
NO Words can describe. How amazing this church is! It is a must see. Next time I hope to go to mass while in Budapest. Go there. You will not be disappointed.

Good atmosphere. Admission is free, but someone stay watching if you give the suggested 200 Ft to go in.Marvellous marbles and granites (in a pretty burgundy collors), beautiful statues, a large dome, the peace atmosphere, everything makes this visit a must.

Marvellous huge church. One of the "must see" attractions in Pest, and well worth a visit to see the huge and ornate interior. Admission is by a "suggested donation" which from memory was a modest amount. See the dome, side-chapels, and the main chapel. If this kind of thing is to your taste, don't miss St Matthias church on tbe Bude hill (if I had to choose, I'd go for St Matthias because of its stunningly decorated interior)

A breath taking interior with stunning views from the top. The basilica is well worth a visit. Dating back to 1851, the interior, full of gold leaf and delicate painting, is truly stunning. Over the top ornate detailing is unlike anything I've ever seen. Not to be missed is the view from the top, where Budapest can be seen from every angle. They host classical music concerts as well, which are certainly worth attending.

No show without Punch...... The day we arrived in Budapest, we spotted a bloke handing out leaflets, promoting concerts in two churches, one of which was St Stephen's. We bought the tickets and made our way over there.It's a very beautiful church, with a fab domed ceiling and is well worth visiting. We didn't bother lighting up the 'hand' - a little too macabre for our liking.The concert was good, with a kind of Classic FM popular hits repertoire, about 12 'tracks', each lasting a relatively short time. The instrumentalists, trumpet and violin, and the singers were very good individually but unfortunately were totally drowned out by the organist. He was a really talented player but simply played too loudly and had no need to play constantly. Some of the performances would have been far more poignant without the organist - as my mother would say, 'there's no show without Punch!'At the end of the concert, we realised that he hadn't actually been playing the real organ, but an electric one - apparently there's only one person who's allowed to play the real one!? So basically there was no excuse for not turning the volume down!

A Must Visit In Budapest. This church is incredible! It does cost a donation to enter but it is well worth it! A heads up females must cover their shoulders when entering. Also pay the extra fee to head up to the top of the church. The view overlooks the entire city of Budapest.

(another) really nice church. I remember that I really liked this church, but can't remember why - I saw a lot of churches in Europe! They won't accept Euros for the lift to the viewing platform (a real pain if you're in Budapest on a day trip and couldn't be bothered to find a safe place to change money!), but they're more than happy to accept donations in Euros!

Beautiful, marbled church - certainly worth a visit. A very lovely church. It has marbled columns and the colors are very pleasing with the gold surroundings. We climbed the dome as well which wasn't that interesting as Budapest isn't really a rooftop-picturesque city, but it is really inexpensive to go up, so you might as well just to snap some panoramic pics.Overall, I definitely recommend a visit.

The hand thing was odd, but.... The odd thing about this attraction is that you can see the hand of St. Stephen (Szt. Istvan) in the chapel, given that you are wiling to spend a couple of hundred forints.But the church and the tower is in itself rather interesting, although the inside of the church a bit gloomy.The views from the tower is very nice. If you are budget traveller however, equally attractive views can be seen for free from the Buda side.

A kaleidoscope of colour and wonderment. This is a wonderful must see when in Budapest, as the colours and sense of granduar is overwhelming.The pictures speak more volumes than I can comprehend words

Impressive.. A very grand church worth looking around, especially as it is donations only. Built and named after the first catholic king it is a big part of Hungarian history. Inside u will also find the preserved hand of st Stephen

Amazing Cathedral in in the Heart of the City. St Stephen's Bazilika is a Catholic Cathedral not too far from Deak Square and Andrassy Avenue. It is essentially tucked away amongst banking buildings, and at first I stumbled upon it by complete accident. If you approach it from the side of the Danube, you are in for a wonderful surprise. The Bazilika stands in the middle of wonderfully renovated open square, and with its "I am the Way, the Truth and Life" inscription on its facade, it is truly magnificent.Its main attraction is holding the relic of St Stephen'r right hand, who is considered to be the founding father of Hungary. "The Holy Right Hand", as it is known, is celebrated in a day-long festivity on the 20th August.The building itself is over a 100 yeard old and was recently renovated. If I remember well, there are some stairs leading up to the gate, so I am not sure about disabled access.Like in most Catholic churches, you are expected not to disturb the service and be dressed modestly. There are a lot of posh weddings happening there, so you can come across some true Hungarian celebrities.

Just another church. After seeing churches and basilicas from Spain throughout Central & South America as well as other parts of the world, one gets saturated. This one is probably no better or worse than any of the others. It's really beautiful inside and worth a visit.

My favorite church of the eight we saw in Europe. You really can't go to Budapest and not go inside the Basilica.
