It's GORGEOUS, and cool to see the Holy Right Hand too (you pay like 50 cents to light up the hand to see it better, but someone had done it already so I took my pictures quickly). Free to go inside, but I would really recommend paying a couple of dollars so that you can go up to the top. You can walk up 364 stairs (we did, and didn't think there was another way - but there's an elevator right across from the booth where you buy the ticket to the top....oops) and then see a glorious 360-degree view of Budapest. Both the Basilica and the Parliament building are exactly 315 feet tall; no building in Budapest is allowed to be taller. Basically it's not an attraction that you can afford to miss (I'm not even a religious person but I still really recommend visiting the great churches in Europe).

Beautiful Church and well worth a walk.... Beautiful Church and well worth a walk around! Entry to the main part of the Church is free of charge. You Can go up to one of the Towers. However, Entry here costs money (didnt try, dont know how much). Overall worth a visit!

Beautiful. Great free attraction in the Pest downtown side of Budapest. Amazing outside and in. Did not get to see the famous "Right Hand" of St-Stephen because exhibit was closed. One of our highlights. Looks amazing at night!

Beautiful inside, great views from the tower. The church was very beautiful inside. It is definitely worth it to pay extra to climb (or take the elevator, way easier) to the top to get some great panoramic views of the city.

Stunning Church. Unless you're getting utterly lashed in Budapest, and then maybe even if you are, you should visit this beautiful church.If you're visiting in August, watch out for short classical music evenings held in the Basilica (and in the Parish Church I think). Various soloists, often accompanied by the organist, play a number of favourite, short classical pieces. Listening to them in this majestic setting, without the hubub of the crowds, was wonderful. Wesbsite is www.concertsinbudapest.com
so much beauty. do not forget to take a visit to the church,the view is beautiful and the basilica huge.i enjoyed the most my visit.

Wonderful, go up to the tower as well!. Most beautiful and huge Basilica! Our girls (age 5 and 9) were so taken by the beauty of it that they even wanted to go back after a couple of days staying in Budapest. Take the time to go up to the tower as well (stairs or elevator). The stunning views from the top will be a big reward!
Beautiful church and great views of the city. Loved this church and all the views from the top of the tower. Free to go in and a small charge to go up top.

Don't miss the Holy Right Hand!. Amazing! Don't miss the Holy Right Hand (preserved right hand of the first king and statefounder cc.1000) at the Chapel behind the High Altar. Bring 2x100 HUF to light up the „Hand”. If the light is on, go to its right side of the relic.

You must climb the tower. The architecture of this church and environs is AMAZING. I was taking photos from every angle, even the top. I walked up to what appeared to be the church entrance. I paid a fee, which was confusing since I thought it was free. Unlike Prague, not every site is for sale in Budapest which was refreshing. I didn't see a sign in English, however, so I paid. And then teh climb began. I thought it rather odd, but I kept climbing. Then I realized that something wasn't quite right, but I couldn't exactly turn around and go back downstairs on the winding staircase with people behind me. It might be important to note that I'm afraid of heights.I get out after a long upstairs hike, and I'm almost grabbing teh wall behind me. It was an extremely windy day and I'm not a heavy woman. However, I took my camera and started taking photos. The view was AMAZING. I managed to walk all of the way around the dome, on shaking legs, and see teh whole view. When I got back around, I realized that the people in front and behind had left. I guess they were afraid of heights too.I would do it all over again just to see the view.The inside of teh church is beautiful too, by the way. But the view from teh tower is breath taking.

One of the most beautiful churches in Europe. This is one of the most fascinating buildings in Budapest. Grandiose and full of life. It is one of the most beautiful of churches I have seen in Europe. A plus side is that it is not as gloomy as some that you visit.

Worth a visit but don't eat in the square!. On our second day in Budapest, we headed straight to St. Stephen's after walking along the Danube. We were unable to find anywhere to eat along the way so we ended up eating at Bazilika cafe & restaurant right next to the basilica and this turned out to be the worst idea possible - our food was terribly salty, small portioned, and the restaurant added on 15% service charge, which is a lot higher than the 10% norm for Hungary. We didn't want to pay it because we were not told ahead of time that we would incur this fee (which was almost 1000 HUF) and it isn't printed on the menu, but they said that all the restaurants in that area charge the same for service and made us pay it.St. Stephen's was a really nice basilica and definately worth a look around since it's free (although you have to pay if you want climb the dome), but if you're going to check it out, don't eat in the square! We noticed a bunch of other restaurants as we walked away, along Andrassy Ave, and this probably would have been a much better choice.
Beautiful church in the heart of Budapest. This is one many great churches in Eastern Europe--striking exterior and beautiul interior. It is the heart of the city with a large square in front.

Climb the tower for the best views in Pest. The Basilica is stunning inside, and the view from the panorama platform must be the best in all of Pest. It's well worth the small admission price and all the steps to get up there. And there are two elevators so even the steps are optional, but then you will miss the view of the top of one of the domes inside the Basilica.

Quite Impressive. The cathedral is a great site to visit. It was just a few blocks from our hotel (which was on the main Andrassy street) making it a very nice walk. We went in the early morning when there was hardly anyone there. It is typically nice but the best part is the very special relic. The cathedral houses the hand of Saint Stephen. It is really cool because it is in a protective glass case and for a few coins the box will light up, revelaing the hand. You can take pictures of it, but be sure to turn off your flash. My flash accidetally went off, and the kind old man just gave me a stern look. It is pretty inetersting. There are also very good little retaurants right in that area to eat at.

Stunning church that dominates a lovely square. It is so hard to believe that this church is just over 100 years old as it's ornate architecture suggests it is much older, but it's beautiful condition suggests it is much younger. The stain-glass windows are delightful, especially in the Jobb Chapel where you find the Holy Relic - the mummified hand of Szent Istvan that is 1000 years old.

Great views, beautiful church. Definitely one for the list of must sees! Take the stairs or lift (small charge for the lift) to the top for great views of the city. Inside the Basilica is beautiful and worth a look even if you are not a big fan of churches. The square outside is also a nice place to stop for a coffee and marvel at the building or just people watch.
Must-See in Budapest. Simply gorgeous. Make sure to go all the way to the top for an amazing view of the city of Budapest.

A must see in Budapest!. We started our morning out early and got to the church before they opened. They unlocked the door at 9am and we walked around before there were loads of other people with us. We intended to go up to the top but that part didn't open until 9:30. The inside of the church is just incredible and just makes you drop your jaw in awe. There was no fee to enter the church itself, but if you want to go to the top for the beautiful views (I highly reccomend) it's 400 ft. We got this confused with another area of the church that costs 300 ft to enter called the treasury. Right now there is a display of things from the 1940s, we were dissapointed we paid to enter this room as it wasn't all that interesting to us, at least not to pay and see it. I've posted pictures of what was in the room.The tower opened at 9:30 and we went up the stairs at first (not realizing the elevator was just across the hallway. We did find the 2nd elevator and got to the top for some glorious views of the city. We were the first ones up there so we had the whole place to ourselves. Don't forget to check out St. Stephen's right hand. It's mummified there and you can see it in it's glass case. You have to put some forints in to turn on the light. We didn't go in that room and my husband is still bummed we didn't get to see it. Mummified hand? Sounds gross to me, but I guess guys go for that kind of stuff. Make this beautiful church a priority on your Budapest list!

So many great features. The facade and square outside of the Bazilika are breathtaking, but the inside is just as good. On the ground floor, you can see St Stephen's hand (a saintly relic). And the view from the top is absolutely incredible!

Worth a visit. The Basilica is in a large square. Thus, you can admire its grandeur from the outside as you approach the basilica. The open space gives you also the opportunity to take photo of the entire church.The inside is quite nice, altghough nothing so splendid. There is also a small museum with ecclestic material. A great plus is the elevator ride to the church's cupola. From there, you have a grat view of the Danube, chain bridge and the Palace.Another plus is the both the Parliament and CHain Bridge are less then 5 minutes away.
